abstract.p: Jeff Greenfield, who has been ABC News's best-known political analyst for 14 years, is leaving ABC in January to join Cable News Network (S)

block.p: Jeff Greenfield, who has been ABC News's best-known political analyst for 14 years, is leaving ABC next month to join the Cable News Network, CNN's new president, Richard Kaplan, announced yesterday.

Mr. Greenfield, who in addition to his prominent role covering politics also served as media critic and as a regular contributor to ''Nightline,'' said yesterday that he had been lured to CNN by the opportunity for more work. He said he expected to be the anchor or co-anchor of a new prime-time news magazine; to fill in for Larry King on Mr. King's interview show, and to report long-form stories and perhaps documentaries.
Jeff Greenfield, who has been ABC News's best-known political analyst for 14 years, is leaving ABC next month to join the Cable News Network, CNN's new president, Richard Kaplan, announced yesterday.

Mr. Greenfield, who in addition to his prominent role covering politics also served as media critic and as a regular contributor to ''Nightline,'' said yesterday that he had been lured to CNN by the opportunity for more work. He said he expected to be the anchor or co-anchor of a new prime-time news magazine; to fill in for Larry King on Mr. King's interview show, and to report long-form stories and perhaps documentaries.
Mr. Greenfield took pains to say his departure was no reflection on ABC News but was ''more a reflection of what CNN was offering.''

Mr. Kaplan, who also came to CNN from a long career at ABC News, also announced the hiring of Judd Rose, a correspondent for ABC's ''Prime Time Live'' since 1989. Both Mr. Rose and Mr. Greenfield will remain based in New York. CNN's headquarters are in Atlanta.
